channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: #174 - First non-developer release of Perl::Lint
item.description:
Hi,

Perl::Lint is being funded by TPF, give it a go! And you've got two days to submit comments on the latest grant proposal.

There's just one month left in 2014. What are you going to release to CPAN or blog about?

Send us links to interesting articles at editors@perlweekly.com — they don't have to be about Perl (but it helps).

Editor #3, Neil
item.dc:subject: list of tags?

item.title: Perl Recruitment by a CPAN contributor
item.description: I'm a Perl programmer and open-source developer who also specialises in Perl recruitment in Europe. If you want to know if you're being paid enough, want some help with your CV, or just want to talk to a recruiter who knows the difference between 'local' and 'my', say hello at: http://perl.careers/.

item.title: One month free Perl Maven Pro subscription
item.description: Have you wondered how do those Perl Maven Pro screencasts look like, but wasn't sure about the money part? Now you can try it for free for one month. But don't wait too much, because this offer is only valid till the end of the week.

item.title: An updated interface to Perl::Critic
item.description: Jeffrey Thalhammer (THALJEF) announced that perlcritic.com (a web interface to his popular Perl::Critic module) has been moved to new hardware and completely rewritten (source in github).

item.title: Using Minion with a REST API
item.description: Brian Medley (BPMEDLEY) describes how he uses Minion as a job queue for sending email.

item.title: Using the Windows text-to-speech API
item.description: Sinan Unur (NANIS) shows how to use the Windows Speech API to convert text to speech.

item.title: Get CPANstats from MetaCPAN using cron
item.description: Getting statistics about CPAN from MetaCPAN.

item.title: Serving static files such as favicon.ico and robots.txt using Plack
item.description: For serving static files such as images, CSS files, JavaScript, or the robots.txt, Plack has an easy solution using the 'Static' middleware.

item.title: RFC Perl for education
item.description: Vytas Dauksa (VYTAS) describes how he thinks Perl could be made more palatable for use in education. It can be summarised as 'enable all the Modern Perl stuff, break backwards compatibility to drop some of the legacy features, and bundle the best of CPAN'.

item.title: Web sites with source code for hacking
item.description: Gabor Szabo (SZABGAB) has started curating a list of Perl-based web sites for which the source is available.

item.title: Building Perl 6 with Visual Studio 2013
item.description: Sinan Unur (NANIS) decided to try and compile Rakudo Perl with Visual Studio 2013, which Microsoft made freely available.

item.title: Get started with Perl 6 one liners
item.description: David Farrell (SILLYMOOS) suggests that a good way to get started with Perl 6 is by writing one-liners.

item.title: TDD is all well and good, but who's testing the tests?
item.description: Sinan Unur (NANIS) demonstrates why we all need to know how to use quotemeta.

item.title: CPAN Testers Summary - October 2014
item.description: Barbie (BARBIE) posted his monthly round-up of news related to CPAN Testers.

item.title: Inside look at TPF's budget process
item.description: Dan Wright describes the budgeting process of The Perl Foundation.

item.title: Mailnesia goes open source
item.description: Peter Baranyi has released the source for mailnesia, a disposable email service.

item.title: Email::MIME::Kit v3 will fix-and-or-break your code
item.description: Rik Signes (RJBS) has released a trial version of Email::MIME::Kit v3, which sorts out encodings, but might temporarily make your life worse, if you were (possibly unknowingly) relying on the previous brokenness.

item.title: Imager::Draw::Hexagon - Draw hexes easily using Imager
item.description: JT Smith (RIZEN) has released Imager::Draw::Hexagon. Given the name, you might be surprised to discover that it's for drawing hexagons using Imager.

item.title: todoist - a script interface to todoist.com
item.description: Neil Bowers (NEILB) created a simple interface to todoist.com, an online todolist service. He also finds it weird writing about himself in the third person.

item.title: Perl::Lint released
item.description: Taiki Kawakami (MOZNION) has released the first non-developer version of Perl::Lint, which was funded by a previous grant.

item.title: Inline grant report #5
item.description: David Oswald (DAVIDO and INGY posted their 5th update on the Inline grant, which mainly covered topics related to module builders.

item.title: IO::All Redux grant proposal
item.description: This is your last chance to comment on INGY and David's latest grant proposal. Comments have to be submitted by November 25th.

item.title: YAPC::NA 2015 to be hosted at Little America
item.description: TPF have announced the location of YAPC::NA 2015. Registrations are already being accepted online: YAPC::NA 2015 registration.

item.title: Meet the YAPC::NA 2015 Team
item.description: David Oswald (DAVIDO introduces the team who will be organising YAPC::NA 2015.

item.title: Videos from the London Perl Workshop
item.description: The videos from the recent LPW are now available online. Start off with I am developer, which will only take you 5 minutes.

item.title: Perl and the Internet of Things
item.description: Mark Keating (oh yeah, no PAUSE id, because he still hasn't released any damn code), posted his thoughts and feelings about the London Perl Workshop 2014. TL;DR: it was awesome, everyone was awesome.

item.title: Stackoverflow perl report
item.description: The ten most rated Perl questions on stackoverflow last week.

item.title: Great modules released last week
item.description: Niceperl's list of highly-rated modules that saw a release in the last week.

item.title: MetaCPAN favourites
item.description: Newly favourited and most favourited distributions on MetaCPAN.

item.title: Simple timestamp generation using POSIX strftime in Perl
item.description: Using strftime() in the POSIX module to generate a simple timestamp, for example to use in a logfile.

item.title: Does the all function really short-circuit?
item.description: Playing with the all function from List::MoreUtils.

item.title: Parsing: top-down versus bottom-up
item.description: Jeffrey Kegler (JKEGL) compares top-down and bottom-up parsing, and explains why the latter has re-emerged as the approach of choice.

item.title: Sacrificial Architecture
item.description: Martin Fowler encourages us to plan for a relatively short lifetime for the code we're designing and writing today.
